Locating Server Configuration Data

When you create a server configuration, you must specify the path to the repository. The Server automatically uses this path for the folders it creates. It also uses this path for the server log files and certain other files that may be created later, such as .dmp files and trace files.

The folders created depend upon whether a Native-I or Native-II vault has been used to create the server configuration. After StarTeam 2005 or StarTeam 2005 Release 2 has been installed, all new server configurations will use Native-II vaults. Previously existing server configurations will use Native-II vaults for new files, but will maintain prior files in a Native-I vault until they are converted.

Attachments (Both Native-I and Native-II Vaults)

By default, the repository has an Attachments folder for the files attached to specific types of items. The location of this folder can be changed by selecting the Configure server option on the StarTeam Administration dialog.

Only Native-II vaults contain these folders:

Hive

Archives Folder
In a Native-II vault, most files in this folder are stored in compressed format. Each archive file name is the MD5 value of its content converted to a 32-digit hex string, to which a .gz extension is added of the file is compressed. The MD5 value is a unique signature; therefore only one instance of a particular file's content exists for any hive, saving a considerable amount of vault storage space.

 

Each revision is stored as a separate file. Files in the Archives directory are organized into subdirectories, which makes browsing and managing the files easier. The files are distributed among 1024 folders within each archive. As the files are converted to Native-II format, the online conversion process moves them to the new directory structure. The location of this file may be changed by going to the Hive Manager dialog, selecting the appropriate hive, and clicking Properties.

 

Cache Folder

In a Native-II vault, the Cache holds uncompressed full versions of the files; these files are organized into subdirectories. The layout of the Cache folder is similar to that of the archive folder. Each hive has a directory path defined for the root of the Cache. The location of the Cache file may be changed by going to the Hive Manager dialog, selecting the appropriate hive, and clicking Properties.

HiveIndex

The HiveIndex folder stores the hive-index.xml file, which contains the properties for each hive used by the server configuration.

 

VSS_Hive or PVCS_Hive

The VSS_Hive and/or PVCS_Hive folders are created if the Server locates a VSS or PVCS installation on the computer where the Server is installed.

 

Only Native-I Vaults contain these folders:

Archive Folder

In a Native-I vault, The revisions of the files that you place under version control are stored in a single Archive folder, unless your server interoperates with PVCS and/or Visual SourceSafe (VSS). The Server uses a proprietary system to store and manage revisions of project files in the Archive folder when its native archive format is used.

 

When a user checks in a working file, the Server locks the counterpart of that file in the Archive folder, to ensure that no one else accesses the file until the check-in process is complete. If the check-in fails, however, the file lock may not be automatically released, so the application allows you to set a maximum vault file lock time.

The location of this file can be changed from the Server Administration dialog by clicking the Verify Native-I Vault icon or selecting this option from the Tools menu.

 

Cache Folder
In a Native-I vault, the Cache folder stores the most recently checked-in revisions (called tip revisions) and copies of the most recently checked-out file revisions. Most other version control systems keep a full copy of the tip revision only. The application checks the Cache for a revision as part of the check-out process, because copying files from the Cache is faster than retrieving and decompressing files from the Archive. The location of this file can be changed from the Server Administration dialog by clicking the Verify Native-I Vault icon or selecting this option from the Tools menu.

 

For information on the settings that affect these folders, see Viewing Server Configuration Options.
